an6.63:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, I will teach you a penetrative exposition of the teaching.

an6.63:1.2.pli: Taṃ suṇātha, sādhukaṃ manasi karotha, bhāsissāmī”ti.
an6.63:1.2.eng: Listen and apply your mind well, I will speak.”

an6.63:1.3.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho te bhikkhū bhagavato paccassosuṃ.

an6.63:2.1.eng: “Mendicants, what is the penetrative exposition of the teaching?

an6.63:2.2.pli: Kāmā, bhikkhave, veditabbā, kāmānaṃ nidānasambhavo veditabbo, kāmānaṃ vemattatā veditabbā, kāmānaṃ vipāko veditabbo, kāmanirodho veditabbo, kāmanirodhagāminī paṭipadā veditabbā.
an6.63:2.2.eng: Sensual pleasures should be known. And their source, diversity, result, cessation, and the practice that leads to their cessation should be known.

an6.63:3.1.pli: Vedanā, bhikkhave, veditabbā, vedanānaṃ nidānasambhavo veditabbo, vedanānaṃ vemattatā veditabbā, vedanānaṃ vipāko veditabbo, vedanānirodho veditabbo, vedanānirodhagāminī paṭipadā veditabbā.
an6.63:3.1.eng: Feelings should be known. And their source, diversity, result, cessation, and the practice that leads to their cessation should be known.

an6.63:4.1.pli: Saññā, bhikkhave, veditabbā, saññānaṃ nidānasambhavo veditabbo, saññānaṃ vemattatā veditabbā, saññānaṃ vipāko veditabbo, saññānirodho veditabbo, saññānirodhagāminī paṭipadā veditabbā.
an6.63:4.1.eng: Perceptions should be known. And their source, diversity, result, cessation, and the practice that leads to their cessation should be known.

an6.63:5.1.pli: Āsavā, bhikkhave, veditabbā, āsavānaṃ nidānasambhavo veditabbo, āsavānaṃ vemattatā veditabbā, āsavānaṃ vipāko veditabbo, āsavanirodho veditabbo, āsavanirodhagāminī paṭipadā veditabbā.
an6.63:5.1.eng: Defilements should be known. And their source, diversity, result, cessation, and the practice that leads to their cessation should be known.

an6.63:6.1.pli: Kammaṃ, bhikkhave, veditabbaṃ, kammānaṃ nidānasambhavo veditabbo, kammānaṃ vemattatā veditabbā, kammānaṃ vipāko veditabbo, kammanirodho veditabbo, kammanirodhagāminī paṭipadā veditabbā.
an6.63:6.1.eng: Deeds should be known. And their source, diversity, result, cessation, and the practice that leads to their cessation should be known.

an6.63:7.1.pli: Dukkhaṃ, bhikkhave, veditabbaṃ, dukkhassa nidānasambhavo veditabbo, dukkhassa vemattatā veditabbā, dukkhassa vipāko veditabbo, dukkhanirodho veditabbo, dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā veditabbā.
an6.63:7.1.eng: Suffering should be known. And its source, diversity, result, cessation, and the practice that leads to its cessation should be known.

an6.63:8.1.pli: ‘Kāmā, bhikkhave, veditabbā, kāmānaṃ nidānasambhavo veditabbo, kāmānaṃ vemattatā veditabbā, kāmānaṃ vipāko veditabbo, kāmanirodho veditabbo, kāmanirodhagāminī paṭipadā veditabbā’ti, iti kho panetaṃ vuttaṃ.
an6.63:8.1.eng: ‘Sensual pleasures should be known. And their source, diversity, result, cessation, and the practice that leads to their cessation should be known.’ That’s what I said,

an6.63:8.2.eng: but why did I say it?

an6.63:8.3.eng: There are these five kinds of sensual stimulation.

an6.63:8.4.pli: cakkhuviññeyyā rūpā iṭṭhā kantā manāpā piyarūpā kāmūpasaṃhitā rajanīyā,
an6.63:8.4.eng: Sights known by the eye, which are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.

an6.63:8.8.pli: kāyaviññeyyā phoṭṭhabbā iṭṭhā kantā manāpā piyarūpā kāmūpasaṃhitā rajanīyā.
an6.63:8.8.eng: Touches known by the body, which are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.

an6.63:8.9.pli: Api ca kho, bhikkhave, nete kāmā kāmaguṇā nāmete ariyassa vinaye vuccanti—
an6.63:8.9.eng: However, these are not sensual pleasures. In the training of the Noble One they’re called ‘kinds of sensual stimulation’.

an6.63:8.10.eng: Greedy intention is a person’s sensual pleasure.

an6.63:8.11.eng: The world’s pretty things aren’t sensual pleasures.

an6.63:8.12.eng: Greedy intention is a person’s sensual pleasure.

an6.63:8.13.eng: The world’s pretty things stay just as they are,

an6.63:8.14.eng: but the attentive remove desire for them.

an6.63:9.1.eng: And what is the source of sensual pleasures?

an6.63:11.1.eng: And what is the diversity of sensual pleasures?

an6.63:11.2.pli: Añño, bhikkhave, kāmo rūpesu, añño kāmo saddesu, añño kāmo gandhesu, añño kāmo rasesu, añño kāmo phoṭṭhabbesu.
an6.63:11.2.eng: The sensual desire for sights, sounds, smells, tastes, and touches are all different.

an6.63:11.3.eng: This is called the diversity of sensual pleasures.

an6.63:12.1.eng: And what is the result of sensual pleasures?

an6.63:12.2.pli: Yaṃ kho, bhikkhave, kāmayamāno tajjaṃ tajjaṃ attabhāvaṃ abhinibbatteti puññabhāgiyaṃ vā apuññabhāgiyaṃ vā, ayaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, kāmānaṃ vipāko.
an6.63:12.2.eng: When one who desires sensual pleasures generates a corresponding incarnation, partaking of either good or bad deeds—this is called the result of sensual pleasures.

an6.63:13.1.eng: And what is the cessation of sensual pleasures?

an6.63:13.2.eng: When contact ceases, sensual pleasures cease.

an6.63:13.3.pli: Ayameva ariyo aṭṭhaṅgiko maggo kāmanirodhagāminī paṭipadā, seyyathidaṃ—
an6.63:13.3.eng: The practice that leads to the cessation of sensual pleasures is simply this noble eightfold path, that is:

an6.63:13.4.pli: sammādiṭṭhi, sammāsaṅkappo, sammāvācā, sammākammanto, sammāājīvo, sammāvāyāmo, sammāsati, sammāsamādhi.
an6.63:13.4.eng: right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right immersion.

an6.63:14.1.pli: Yato kho, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako evaṃ kāme pajānāti, evaṃ kāmānaṃ nidānasambhavaṃ pajānāti, evaṃ kāmānaṃ vemattataṃ pajānāti, evaṃ kāmānaṃ vipākaṃ pajānāti, evaṃ kāmanirodhaṃ pajānāti, evaṃ kāmanirodhagāminiṃ paṭipadaṃ pajānāti, so imaṃ nibbedhikaṃ brahmacariyaṃ pajānāti kāmanirodhaṃ.
an6.63:14.1.eng: When a noble disciple understands sensual pleasures in this way—and understands their source, diversity, result, cessation, and the practice that leads to their cessation—they understand that this penetrative spiritual life is the cessation of sensual pleasures.

an6.63:14.2.pli: Kāmā, bhikkhave, veditabbā …pe… kāmanirodhagāminī paṭipadā veditabbāti,
an6.63:14.2.eng: ‘Sensual pleasures should be known. And their source, diversity, result, cessation, and the practice that leads to their cessation should be known.’

an6.63:14.3.pli: iti yaṃ taṃ vuttaṃ idametaṃ paṭicca vuttaṃ.
an6.63:14.3.eng: That’s what I said, and this is why I said it.

an6.63:15.1.pli: Vedanā, bhikkhave, veditabbā …pe… vedanānirodhagāminī paṭipadā veditabbāti,
an6.63:15.1.eng: ‘Feelings should be known. And their source, diversity, result, cessation, and the practice that leads to their cessation should be known.’

an6.63:15.2.pli: iti kho panetaṃ vuttaṃ. Kiñcetaṃ paṭicca vuttaṃ?
an6.63:15.2.eng: That’s what I said, but why did I say it?

an6.63:15.4.pli: sukhā vedanā, dukkhā vedanā, adukkhamasukhā vedanā.

an6.63:16.1.eng: And what is the source of feelings?

an6.63:17.1.eng: And what is the diversity of feelings?

an6.63:17.2.pli: Atthi, bhikkhave, sāmisā sukhā vedanā, atthi nirāmisā sukhā vedanā, atthi sāmisā dukkhā vedanā, atthi nirāmisā dukkhā vedanā, atthi sāmisā adukkhamasukhā vedanā, atthi nirāmisā adukkhamasukhā vedanā.
an6.63:17.2.eng: There are pleasant feelings of the flesh, pleasant feelings not of the flesh, painful feelings of the flesh, painful feelings not of the flesh, neutral feelings of the flesh, and neutral feelings not of the flesh.

an6.63:17.3.eng: This is called the disparity of feelings.

an6.63:18.1.eng: And what is the result of feelings?

an6.63:18.2.pli: Yaṃ kho, bhikkhave, vediyamāno tajjaṃ tajjaṃ attabhāvaṃ abhinibbatteti puññabhāgiyaṃ vā apuññabhāgiyaṃ vā,
an6.63:18.2.eng: When one who feels generates a corresponding incarnation, partaking of either good or bad deeds—

an6.63:18.3.eng: this is called the result of feelings.

an6.63:19.1.eng: And what is the cessation of feelings?

an6.63:19.3.pli: Ayameva ariyo aṭṭhaṅgiko maggo vedanānirodhagāminī paṭipadā, seyyathidaṃ—
an6.63:19.3.eng: The practice that leads to the cessation of feelings is simply this noble eightfold path, that is:

an6.63:19.4.eng: right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right immersion.

an6.63:20.1.pli: Yato kho, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako evaṃ vedanaṃ pajānāti, evaṃ vedanānaṃ nidānasambhavaṃ pajānāti, evaṃ vedanānaṃ vemattataṃ pajānāti, evaṃ vedanānaṃ vipākaṃ pajānāti, evaṃ vedanānirodhaṃ pajānāti, evaṃ vedanānirodhagāminiṃ paṭipadaṃ pajānāti. So imaṃ nibbedhikaṃ brahmacariyaṃ pajānāti vedanānirodhaṃ.
an6.63:20.1.eng: When a noble disciple understands feelings in this way … they understand that this penetrative spiritual life is the cessation of feelings.

an6.63:20.2.pli: Vedanā, bhikkhave, veditabbā …pe… vedanānirodhagāminī paṭipadā veditabbāti,
an6.63:20.2.eng: ‘Feelings should be known. And their source, diversity, result, cessation, and the practice that leads to their cessation should be known.’

an6.63:20.3.pli: iti yaṃ taṃ vuttaṃ idametaṃ paṭicca vuttaṃ.
an6.63:20.3.eng: That’s what I said, and this is why I said it.

an6.63:21.1.pli: Saññā, bhikkhave, veditabbā …pe… saññānirodhagāminī paṭipadā veditabbāti,
an6.63:21.1.eng: ‘Perceptions should be known. And their source, diversity, result, cessation, and the practice that leads to their cessation should be known.’

an6.63:21.2.pli: iti kho panetaṃ vuttaṃ. Kiñcetaṃ paṭicca vuttaṃ?
an6.63:21.2.eng: That’s what I said, but why did I say it?

an6.63:21.4.pli: rūpasaññā, saddasaññā, gandhasaññā, rasasaññā, phoṭṭhabbasaññā, dhammasaññā.
an6.63:21.4.eng: perceptions of sights, sounds, smells, tastes, touches, and ideas.

an6.63:22.1.eng: And what is the source of perceptions?

an6.63:23.1.eng: And what is the diversity of perceptions?

an6.63:23.2.pli: Aññā, bhikkhave, saññā rūpesu, aññā saññā saddesu, aññā saññā gandhesu, aññā saññā rasesu, aññā saññā phoṭṭhabbesu, aññā saññā dhammesu.
an6.63:23.2.eng: The perceptions of sights, sounds, smells, tastes, touches, and ideas are all different.

an6.63:23.3.eng: This is called the diversity of perceptions.

an6.63:24.1.eng: And what is the result of perceptions?

an6.63:24.2.eng: Communication is the result of perception, I say.

an6.63:24.3.pli: Yathā yathā naṃ sañjānāti tathā tathā voharati, evaṃ saññī ahosinti.
an6.63:24.3.eng: You communicate something in whatever manner you perceive it, saying ‘That’s what I perceived.’

an6.63:24.4.eng: This is called the result of perceptions.

an6.63:25.1.eng: And what is the cessation of perception?

an6.63:25.3.pli: Ayameva ariyo aṭṭhaṅgiko maggo saññānirodhagāminī paṭipadā, seyyathidaṃ—
an6.63:25.3.eng: The practice that leads to the cessation of perceptions is simply this noble eightfold path, that is:

an6.63:25.4.eng: right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right immersion.

an6.63:26.1.pli: Yato kho, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako evaṃ saññaṃ pajānāti, evaṃ saññānaṃ nidānasambhavaṃ pajānāti, evaṃ saññānaṃ vemattataṃ pajānāti, evaṃ saññānaṃ vipākaṃ pajānāti, evaṃ saññānirodhaṃ pajānāti, evaṃ saññānirodhagāminiṃ paṭipadaṃ pajānāti, so imaṃ nibbedhikaṃ brahmacariyaṃ pajānāti saññānirodhaṃ.
an6.63:26.1.eng: When a noble disciple understands perception in this way … they understand that this penetrative spiritual life is the cessation of perception.

an6.63:26.2.pli: Saññā, bhikkhave, veditabbā …pe… saññānirodhagāminī paṭipadā veditabbāti.
an6.63:26.2.eng: ‘Perceptions should be known. And their source, diversity, result, cessation, and the practice that leads to their cessation should be known.’

an6.63:26.3.pli: Iti yaṃ taṃ vuttaṃ idametaṃ paṭicca vuttaṃ.
an6.63:26.3.eng: That’s what I said, and this is why I said it.

an6.63:27.1.pli: Āsavā, bhikkhave, veditabbā …pe… āsavanirodhagāminī paṭipadā veditabbāti,
an6.63:27.1.eng: ‘Defilements should be known. And their source, diversity, result, cessation, and the practice that leads to their cessation should be known.’

an6.63:27.2.pli: iti kho panetaṃ vuttaṃ. Kiñcetaṃ paṭicca vuttaṃ?
an6.63:27.2.eng: That’s what I said, but why did I say it?

an6.63:27.4.eng: the defilements of sensuality, desire to be reborn, and ignorance.

an6.63:28.1.eng: And what is the source of defilements?

an6.63:28.2.eng: Ignorance is the source of defilements.

an6.63:29.1.eng: And what is the disparity of defilements?

an6.63:29.2.pli: Atthi, bhikkhave, āsavā nirayagamanīyā, atthi āsavā tiracchānayonigamanīyā, atthi āsavā pettivisayagamanīyā, atthi āsavā manussalokagamanīyā, atthi āsavā devalokagamanīyā.
an6.63:29.2.eng: There are defilements that lead to rebirth in hell, the animal realm, the ghost realm, the human world, and the world of the gods.

an6.63:29.3.eng: This is called the disparity of defilements.

an6.63:30.1.eng: And what is the result of defilements?

an6.63:30.2.pli: Yaṃ kho, bhikkhave, avijjāgato tajjaṃ tajjaṃ attabhāvaṃ abhinibbatteti puññabhāgiyaṃ vā apuññabhāgiyaṃ vā, ayaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, āsavānaṃ vipāko.
an6.63:30.2.eng: When one who is ignorant generates a corresponding incarnation, partaking of either good or bad deeds—this is called the result of defilements.

an6.63:31.1.eng: And what is the cessation of defilements?

an6.63:31.3.pli: Ayameva ariyo aṭṭhaṅgiko maggo āsavanirodhagāminī paṭipadā, seyyathidaṃ—
an6.63:31.3.eng: The practice that leads to the cessation of defilements is simply this noble eightfold path, that is:

an6.63:31.4.eng: right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right immersion.

an6.63:32.1.pli: Yato kho, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako evaṃ āsave pajānāti, evaṃ āsavānaṃ nidānasambhavaṃ pajānāti, evaṃ āsavānaṃ vemattataṃ pajānāti, evaṃ āsavānaṃ vipākaṃ pajānāti, evaṃ āsavānaṃ nirodhaṃ pajānāti, evaṃ āsavānaṃ nirodhagāminiṃ paṭipadaṃ pajānāti, so imaṃ nibbedhikaṃ brahmacariyaṃ pajānāti āsavanirodhaṃ.
an6.63:32.1.eng: When a noble disciple understands defilements in this way … they understand that this penetrative spiritual life is the cessation of defilements.

an6.63:32.2.pli: Āsavā, bhikkhave, veditabbā …pe… āsavanirodhagāminī paṭipadā veditabbāti.
an6.63:32.2.eng: ‘Defilements should be known. And their source, diversity, result, cessation, and the practice that leads to their cessation should be known.’

an6.63:32.3.pli: Iti yaṃ taṃ vuttaṃ idametaṃ paṭicca vuttaṃ.
an6.63:32.3.eng: That’s what I said, and this is why I said it.

an6.63:33.1.pli: Kammaṃ, bhikkhave, veditabbaṃ …pe… kammanirodhagāminī paṭipadā veditabbāti, iti kho panetaṃ vuttaṃ.
an6.63:33.1.eng: ‘Deeds should be known. And their source, diversity, result, cessation, and the practice that leads to their cessation should be known.’ That’s what I said,

an6.63:33.2.eng: but why did I say it?

an6.63:33.3.eng: It is intention that I call deeds.

an6.63:33.4.eng: For after making a choice one acts

an6.63:33.5.eng: by way of body, speech, and mind.

an6.63:34.1.eng: And what is the source of deeds?

an6.63:35.1.eng: And what is the disparity of deeds?

an6.63:35.2.pli: Atthi, bhikkhave, kammaṃ nirayavedanīyaṃ, atthi kammaṃ tiracchānayonivedanīyaṃ, atthi kammaṃ pettivisayavedanīyaṃ, atthi kammaṃ manussalokavedanīyaṃ, atthi kammaṃ devalokavedanīyaṃ.
an6.63:35.2.eng: There are deeds that lead to rebirth in hell, the animal realm, the ghost realm, the human world, and the world of the gods.

an6.63:35.3.eng: This is called the disparity of deeds.

an6.63:36.1.eng: And what is the result of deeds?

an6.63:36.2.eng: The result of deeds is threefold, I say:

an6.63:36.3.pli: diṭṭheva dhamme, upapajje vā, apare vā pariyāye.
an6.63:36.3.eng: in this very life, on rebirth in the next life, or at some later time.

an6.63:36.4.eng: This is called the result of deeds.

an6.63:37.1.eng: And what is the cessation of deeds?

an6.63:37.3.pli: Ayameva ariyo aṭṭhaṅgiko maggo kammanirodhagāminī paṭipadā, seyyathidaṃ—
an6.63:37.3.eng: The practice that leads to the cessation of deeds is simply this noble eightfold path, that is:

an6.63:37.4.eng: right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right immersion.

an6.63:38.1.pli: Yato kho, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako evaṃ kammaṃ pajānāti, evaṃ kammānaṃ nidānasambhavaṃ pajānāti, evaṃ kammānaṃ vemattataṃ pajānāti, evaṃ kammānaṃ vipākaṃ pajānāti, evaṃ kammanirodhaṃ pajānāti, evaṃ kammanirodhagāminiṃ paṭipadaṃ pajānāti, so imaṃ nibbedhikaṃ brahmacariyaṃ pajānāti kammanirodhaṃ.
an6.63:38.1.eng: When a noble disciple understands deeds in this way … they understand that this penetrative spiritual life is the cessation of deeds.

an6.63:38.2.pli: Kammaṃ, bhikkhave, veditabbaṃ …pe… kammanirodhagāminī paṭipadā veditabbāti,
an6.63:38.2.eng: ‘Deeds should be known. And their source, diversity, result, cessation, and the practice that leads to their cessation should be known.’

an6.63:38.3.pli: iti yaṃ taṃ vuttaṃ idametaṃ paṭicca vuttaṃ.
an6.63:38.3.eng: That’s what I said, and this is why I said it.

an6.63:39.1.pli: Dukkhaṃ, bhikkhave, veditabbaṃ, dukkhassa nidānasambhavo veditabbo, dukkhassa vemattatā veditabbā, dukkhassa vipāko veditabbo, dukkhanirodho veditabbo, dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā veditabbāti.
an6.63:39.1.eng: ‘Suffering should be known. And its source, disparity, result, cessation, and the practice that leads to its cessation should be known.’

an6.63:39.2.pli: Iti kho panetaṃ vuttaṃ, kiñcetaṃ paṭicca vuttaṃ?
an6.63:39.2.eng: That’s what I said, but why did I say it?

an6.63:39.3.pli: Jātipi dukkhā, jarāpi dukkhā, byādhipi dukkho, maraṇampi dukkhaṃ, sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsāpi dukkhā, yampicchaṃ na labhati tampi dukkhaṃ, saṅkhittena pañcupādānakkhandhā dukkhā.
an6.63:39.3.eng: Rebirth is suffering; old age is suffering; illness is suffering; death is suffering; sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress are suffering; not getting what you wish for is suffering. In brief, the five grasping aggregates are suffering.

an6.63:40.1.eng: And what is the source of suffering?

an6.63:40.2.eng: Craving is the source of suffering.

an6.63:41.1.eng: And what is the disparity of suffering?

an6.63:41.2.pli: Atthi, bhikkhave, dukkhaṃ adhimattaṃ, atthi parittaṃ, atthi dandhavirāgi, atthi khippavirāgi.
an6.63:41.2.eng: There is suffering that is severe, mild, slow to fade, and quick to fade.

an6.63:41.3.eng: This is called the disparity of suffering.

an6.63:42.1.eng: And what is the result of suffering?

an6.63:42.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco yena dukkhena abhibhūto pariyādinnacitto socati kilamati paridevati, urattāḷiṃ kandati, sammohaṃ āpajjati, yena vā pana dukkhena abhibhūto pariyādinnacitto bahiddhā pariyeṭṭhiṃ āpajjati:
an6.63:42.2.eng: It’s when someone who is overcome and overwhelmed by suffering sorrows and wails and laments, beating their breast and falling into confusion. Or else, overcome by that suffering, they begin an external search, wondering:

an6.63:42.3.pli: ‘ko ekapadaṃ dvipadaṃ jānāti imassa dukkhassa nirodhāyā’ti?
an6.63:42.3.eng: ‘Who knows one or two phrases to stop this suffering?’

an6.63:42.4.pli: Sammohavepakkaṃ vāhaṃ, bhikkhave, dukkhaṃ vadāmi pariyeṭṭhivepakkaṃ vā.
an6.63:42.4.eng: The result of suffering is either confusion or a search, I say.

an6.63:42.5.eng: This is called the result of suffering.

an6.63:43.1.eng: And what is the cessation of suffering?

an6.63:43.3.pli: Ayameva ariyo aṭṭhaṅgiko maggo dukkhassa nirodhagāminī paṭipadā, seyyathidaṃ—
an6.63:43.3.eng: The practice that leads to the cessation of suffering is simply this noble eightfold path, that is:

an6.63:43.4.eng: right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right immersion.

an6.63:44.1.pli: Yato kho, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako evaṃ dukkhaṃ pajānāti, evaṃ dukkhassa nidānasambhavaṃ pajānāti, evaṃ dukkhassa vemattataṃ pajānāti, evaṃ dukkhassa vipākaṃ pajānāti, evaṃ dukkhanirodhaṃ pajānāti, evaṃ dukkhanirodhagāminiṃ paṭipadaṃ pajānāti, so imaṃ nibbedhikaṃ brahmacariyaṃ pajānāti dukkhanirodhaṃ.
an6.63:44.1.eng: When a noble disciple understands suffering in this way … they understand that this penetrative spiritual life is the cessation of suffering.

an6.63:44.2.pli: Dukkhaṃ, bhikkhave, veditabbaṃ, dukkhassa nidānasambhavo veditabbo, dukkhassa vemattatā veditabbā, dukkhassa vipāko veditabbo, dukkhanirodho veditabbo, dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā veditabbāti.
an6.63:44.2.eng: ‘Suffering should be known. And its source, diversity, result, cessation, and the practice that leads to its cessation should be known.’

an6.63:44.3.pli: Iti yaṃ taṃ vuttaṃ idametaṃ paṭicca vuttaṃ.
an6.63:44.3.eng: That’s what I said, and this is why I said it.

an6.63:45.1.pli: Ayaṃ kho so, bhikkhave, nibbedhikapariyāyo dhammapariyāyo”ti.
an6.63:45.1.eng: This is the penetrative exposition of the teaching.”

an6.64:1.1.pli: “Chayimāni, bhikkhave, tathāgatassa tathāgatabalāni, yehi balehi samannāgato tathāgato āsabhaṃ ṭhānaṃ paṭijānāti, parisāsu sīhanādaṃ nadati, brahmacakkaṃ pavatteti.
an6.64:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, the Realized One possesses six powers of a Realized One. With these he claims the bull’s place, roars his lion’s roar in the assemblies, and turns the divine wheel.

an6.64:1.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, tathāgato ṭhānañca ṭhānato aṭṭhānañca aṭṭhānato yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti.
an6.64:1.3.eng: Firstly, the Realized One truly understands the possible as possible and the impossible as impossible.

an6.64:1.4.pli: Yampi, bhikkhave, tathāgato ṭhānañca ṭhānato aṭṭhānañca aṭṭhānato yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti, idampi, bhikkhave, tathāgatassa tathāgatabalaṃ hoti, yaṃ balaṃ āgamma tathāgato āsabhaṃ ṭhānaṃ paṭijānāti, parisāsu sīhanādaṃ nadati, brahmacakkaṃ pavatteti.
an6.64:1.4.eng: Since he truly understands this, this is a power of the Realized One. Relying on this he claims the bull’s place, roars his lion’s roar in the assemblies, and turns the divine wheel.

an6.64:2.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, tathāgato atītānāgatapaccuppannānaṃ kammasamādānānaṃ ṭhānaso hetuso vipākaṃ yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti.
an6.64:2.1.eng: Furthermore, the Realized One truly understands the result of deeds undertaken in the past, future, and present in terms of grounds and causes.

an6.64:2.2.pli: Yampi, bhikkhave, tathāgato atītānāgatapaccuppannānaṃ kammasamādānānaṃ ṭhānaso hetuso vipākaṃ yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti, idampi, bhikkhave, tathāgatassa tathāgatabalaṃ hoti, yaṃ balaṃ āgamma tathāgato āsabhaṃ ṭhānaṃ paṭijānāti, parisāsu sīhanādaṃ nadati, brahmacakkaṃ pavatteti.
an6.64:2.2.eng: Since he truly understands this, this is a power of the Realized One. …

an6.64:3.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, tathāgato jhānavimokkhasamādhisamāpattīnaṃ saṅkilesaṃ vodānaṃ vuṭṭhānaṃ yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti.
an6.64:3.1.eng: Furthermore, the Realized One truly understands corruption, cleansing, and emergence regarding the absorptions, liberations, immersions, and attainments.

an6.64:3.2.pli: Yampi, bhikkhave, tathāgato …pe… idampi, bhikkhave, tathāgatassa tathāgatabalaṃ hoti, yaṃ balaṃ āgamma tathāgato āsabhaṃ ṭhānaṃ paṭijānāti, parisāsu sīhanādaṃ nadati, brahmacakkaṃ pavatteti.
an6.64:3.2.eng: Since he truly understands this, this is a power of the Realized One. …

an6.64:4.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, tathāgato anekavihitaṃ pubbenivāsaṃ anussarati, seyyathidaṃ—ekampi jātiṃ, dvepi jātiyo …pe… iti sākāraṃ sauddesaṃ anekavihitaṃ pubbenivāsaṃ anussarati.
an6.64:4.1.eng: Furthermore, the Realized One recollects many kinds of past lives. That is: one, two, three, four, five, ten, twenty, thirty, forty, fifty, a hundred, a thousand, a hundred thousand rebirths; many eons of the world contracting, many eons of the world expanding, many eons of the world contracting and expanding. He remembers: ‘There, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn somewhere else. There, too, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn here.’ And so he recollects his many kinds of past lives, with features and details.

an6.64:4.2.pli: Yampi, bhikkhave, tathāgato anekavihitaṃ pubbenivāsaṃ anussarati, seyyathidaṃ—ekampi jātiṃ, dvepi jātiyo …pe… iti sākāraṃ sauddesaṃ anekavihitaṃ pubbenivāsaṃ anussarati, idampi, bhikkhave, tathāgatassa tathāgatabalaṃ hoti, yaṃ balaṃ āgamma tathāgato āsabhaṃ ṭhānaṃ paṭijānāti, parisāsu sīhanādaṃ nadati, brahmacakkaṃ pavatteti.
an6.64:4.2.eng: Since he truly understands this, this is a power of the Realized One. …

an6.64:5.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, tathāgato dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena …pe… yathākammūpage satte pajānāti.
an6.64:5.1.eng: Furthermore, with clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, the Realized One sees sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place. He understands how sentient beings pass on according to their deeds.

an6.64:5.2.pli: Yampi, bhikkhave, tathāgato dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena …pe… yathākammūpage satte pajānāti, idampi, bhikkhave, tathāgatassa tathāgatabalaṃ hoti, yaṃ balaṃ āgamma tathāgato āsabhaṃ ṭhānaṃ paṭijānāti, parisāsu sīhanādaṃ nadati, brahmacakkaṃ pavatteti.
an6.64:5.2.eng: Since he truly understands this, this is a power of the Realized One. …

an6.64:6.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, tathāgato āsavānaṃ khayā …pe… sacchikatvā upasampajja viharati.
an6.64:6.1.eng: Furthermore, the Realized One has realized the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life. And he lives having realized it with his own insight due to the ending of defilements.

an6.64:6.2.pli: Yampi, bhikkhave, tathāgato āsavānaṃ khayā …pe… sacchikatvā upasampajja viharati, idampi, bhikkhave, tathāgatassa tathāgatabalaṃ hoti, yaṃ balaṃ āgamma tathāgato āsabhaṃ ṭhānaṃ paṭijānāti, parisāsu sīhanādaṃ nadati, brahmacakkaṃ pavatteti.
an6.64:6.2.eng: Since he truly understands this, this is a power of the Realized One. Relying on this he claims the bull’s place, roars his lion’s roar in the assemblies, and turns the divine wheel.

an6.64:6.3.pli: Imāni kho, bhikkhave, cha tathāgatassa tathāgatabalāni, yehi balehi samannāgato tathāgato āsabhaṃ ṭhānaṃ paṭijānāti, parisāsu sīhanādaṃ nadati, brahmacakkaṃ pavatteti.
an6.64:6.3.eng: These are the six powers of a Realized One that the Realized One possesses. With these he claims the bull’s place, roars his lion’s roar in the assemblies, and turns the divine wheel.

an6.64:7.1.pli: Tatra ce, bhikkhave, pare tathāgataṃ ṭhānañca ṭhānato aṭṭhānañca aṭṭhānato yathābhūtaṃ ñāṇena upasaṅkamitvā pañhaṃ pucchanti.
an6.64:7.1.eng: If others come to the Realized One and ask questions about his true knowledge of the possible as possible and the impossible as impossible,

an6.64:7.2.pli: Yathā yathā, bhikkhave, tathāgatassa ṭhānañca ṭhānato aṭṭhānañca aṭṭhānato yathābhūtaṃ ñāṇaṃ viditaṃ tathā tathā tesaṃ tathāgato ṭhānañca ṭhānato aṭṭhānañca aṭṭhānato yathābhūtaṃ ñāṇena pañhaṃ puṭṭho byākaroti.
an6.64:7.2.eng: the Realized One answers them in whatever manner he has truly known it.

an6.64:8.1.pli: Tatra ce, bhikkhave, pare tathāgataṃ atītānāgatapaccuppannānaṃ kammasamādānānaṃ ṭhānaso hetuso vipākaṃ yathābhūtaṃ ñāṇena upasaṅkamitvā pañhaṃ pucchanti.
an6.64:8.1.eng: If others come to the Realized One and ask questions about his true knowledge of the result of deeds undertaken in the past, future, and present in terms of grounds and causes,

an6.64:8.2.pli: Yathā yathā, bhikkhave, tathāgatassa atītānāgatapaccuppannānaṃ kammasamādānānaṃ ṭhānaso hetuso vipākaṃ yathābhūtaṃ ñāṇaṃ viditaṃ tathā tathā tesaṃ tathāgato atītānāgatapaccuppannānaṃ kammasamādānānaṃ ṭhānaso hetuso vipākaṃ yathābhūtaṃ ñāṇena pañhaṃ puṭṭho byākaroti.
an6.64:8.2.eng: the Realized One answers them in whatever manner he has truly known it.

an6.64:9.1.pli: Tatra ce, bhikkhave, pare tathāgataṃ jhānavimokkhasamādhisamāpattīnaṃ saṅkilesaṃ vodānaṃ vuṭṭhānaṃ yathābhūtaṃ ñāṇena upasaṅkamitvā pañhaṃ pucchanti.
an6.64:9.1.eng: If others come to the Realized One and ask questions about his true knowledge of corruption, cleansing, and emergence regarding the absorptions, liberations, immersions, and attainments,

an6.64:9.2.pli: Yathā yathā, bhikkhave, tathāgatassa jhānavimokkhasamādhisamāpattīnaṃ saṅkilesaṃ vodānaṃ vuṭṭhānaṃ yathābhūtaṃ ñāṇaṃ viditaṃ tathā tathā tesaṃ tathāgato jhānavimokkhasamādhisamāpattīnaṃ saṅkilesaṃ vodānaṃ vuṭṭhānaṃ yathābhūtaṃ ñāṇena pañhaṃ puṭṭho byākaroti.
an6.64:9.2.eng: the Realized One answers them in whatever manner he has truly known it.

an6.64:10.1.pli: Tatra ce, bhikkhave, pare tathāgataṃ pubbenivāsānussatiṃ yathābhūtaṃ ñāṇena upasaṅkamitvā pañhaṃ pucchanti.
an6.64:10.1.eng: If others come to the Realized One and ask questions about his true knowledge of recollection of past lives,

an6.64:10.2.pli: Yathā yathā, bhikkhave, tathāgatassa pubbenivāsānussatiṃ yathābhūtaṃ ñāṇaṃ viditaṃ tathā tathā tesaṃ tathāgato pubbenivāsānussatiṃ yathābhūtaṃ ñāṇena pañhaṃ puṭṭho byākaroti.
an6.64:10.2.eng: the Realized One answers them in whatever manner he has truly known it.

an6.64:11.1.pli: Tatra ce, bhikkhave, pare tathāgataṃ sattānaṃ cutūpapātaṃ yathābhūtaṃ ñāṇena upasaṅkamitvā pañhaṃ pucchanti.
an6.64:11.1.eng: If others come to the Realized One and ask questions about his true knowledge of passing away and rebirth of sentient beings,

an6.64:11.2.pli: Yathā yathā, bhikkhave, tathāgatassa sattānaṃ cutūpapātaṃ yathābhūtaṃ ñāṇaṃ viditaṃ tathā tathā tesaṃ tathāgato sattānaṃ cutūpapātaṃ yathābhūtaṃ ñāṇena pañhaṃ puṭṭho byākaroti.
an6.64:11.2.eng: the Realized One answers them in whatever manner he has truly known it.

an6.64:12.1.pli: Tatra ce, bhikkhave, pare tathāgataṃ āsavānaṃ khayā …pe… yathābhūtaṃ ñāṇena upasaṅkamitvā pañhaṃ pucchanti.
an6.64:12.1.eng: If others come to the Realized One and ask questions about his true knowledge of the ending of defilements,

an6.64:12.2.pli: Yathā yathā, bhikkhave, tathāgatassa āsavānaṃ khayā …pe… yathābhūtaṃ ñāṇaṃ viditaṃ tathā tathā tesaṃ tathāgato āsavānaṃ khayā …pe… yathābhūtaṃ ñāṇena pañhaṃ puṭṭho byākaroti.
an6.64:12.2.eng: the Realized One answers them in whatever manner he has truly known it.

an6.64:13.1.pli: Tatra, bhikkhave, yampidaṃ ṭhānañca ṭhānato aṭṭhānañca aṭṭhānato yathābhūtaṃ ñāṇaṃ tampi samāhitassa vadāmi no asamāhitassa.
an6.64:13.1.eng: And I say that true knowledge of the possible as possible and the impossible as impossible is for those with immersion, not for those without immersion.

an6.64:13.2.pli: Yampidaṃ atītānāgatapaccuppannānaṃ kammasamādānānaṃ ṭhānaso hetuso vipākaṃ yathābhūtaṃ ñāṇaṃ tampi samāhitassa vadāmi no asamāhitassa.
an6.64:13.2.eng: And true knowledge of the result of deeds undertaken in the past, future, and present in terms of grounds and causes is for those with immersion, not for those without immersion.

an6.64:13.3.pli: Yampidaṃ jhānavimokkhasamādhisamāpattīnaṃ saṅkilesaṃ vodānaṃ vuṭṭhānaṃ yathābhūtaṃ ñāṇaṃ tampi samāhitassa vadāmi no asamāhitassa.
an6.64:13.3.eng: And true knowledge of corruption, cleansing, and emergence regarding the absorptions, liberations, immersions, and attainments is for those with immersion, not for those without immersion.

an6.64:13.4.pli: Yampidaṃ pubbenivāsānussatiṃ yathābhūtaṃ ñāṇaṃ tampi samāhitassa vadāmi no asamāhitassa.
an6.64:13.4.eng: And true knowledge of the recollection of past lives is for those with immersion, not for those without immersion.

an6.64:13.5.pli: Yampidaṃ sattānaṃ cutūpapātaṃ yathābhūtaṃ ñāṇaṃ tampi samāhitassa vadāmi no asamāhitassa.
an6.64:13.5.eng: And true knowledge of the passing away and rebirth of sentient beings is for those with immersion, not for those without immersion.

an6.64:13.6.pli: Yampidaṃ āsavānaṃ khayā …pe… yathābhūtaṃ ñāṇaṃ tampi samāhitassa vadāmi no asamāhitassa.
an6.64:13.6.eng: And true knowledge of the ending of defilements is for those with immersion, not for those without immersion.

an6.64:13.7.pli: Iti kho, bhikkhave, samādhi maggo, asamādhi kummaggo”ti.
an6.64:13.7.eng: And so, mendicants, immersion is the path. No immersion is the wrong path.”

an6.65:1.1.pli: “Cha, bhikkhave, dhamme appahāya abhabbo anāgāmiphalaṃ sacchikātuṃ.
an6.65:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, without giving up six things you can’t realize the fruit of non-return.

an6.65:1.3.pli: Assaddhiyaṃ, ahirikaṃ, anottappaṃ, kosajjaṃ, muṭṭhassaccaṃ, duppaññataṃ—
an6.65:1.3.eng: Lack of faith, conscience, and prudence; laziness, unmindfulness, and witlessness.

an6.65:1.4.pli: ime kho, bhikkhave, cha dhamme appahāya abhabbo anāgāmiphalaṃ sacchikātuṃ.
an6.65:1.4.eng: Without giving up these six things you can’t realize the fruit of non-return.

an6.65:2.1.pli: Cha, bhikkhave, dhamme pahāya bhabbo anāgāmiphalaṃ sacchikātuṃ.
an6.65:2.1.eng: After giving up six things you can realize the fruit of non-return.

an6.65:2.3.pli: Assaddhiyaṃ, ahirikaṃ, anottappaṃ, kosajjaṃ, muṭṭhassaccaṃ, duppaññataṃ—
an6.65:2.3.eng: Lack of faith, conscience, and prudence; laziness, unmindfulness, and witlessness.

an6.65:2.4.pli: ime kho, bhikkhave, cha dhamme pahāya bhabbo anāgāmiphalaṃ sacchikātun”ti.
an6.65:2.4.eng: After giving up these six things you can realize the fruit of non-return.”

an6.66:1.1.pli: “Cha, bhikkhave, dhamme appahāya abhabbo arahattaṃ sacchikātuṃ.
an6.66:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, without giving up six things you can’t realize perfection.

an6.66:1.3.pli: Thinaṃ, middhaṃ, uddhaccaṃ, kukkuccaṃ, assaddhiyaṃ, pamādaṃ—
an6.66:1.3.eng: Dullness, drowsiness, restlessness, remorse, lack of faith, and negligence.

an6.66:1.4.pli: ime kho, bhikkhave, cha dhamme appahāya abhabbo arahattaṃ sacchikātuṃ.
an6.66:1.4.eng: Without giving up these six things you can’t realize perfection.

an6.66:2.1.pli: Cha, bhikkhave, dhamme pahāya bhabbo arahattaṃ sacchikātuṃ.
an6.66:2.1.eng: After giving up six things you can realize perfection.

an6.66:2.3.pli: Thinaṃ, middhaṃ, uddhaccaṃ, kukkuccaṃ, assaddhiyaṃ, pamādaṃ—
an6.66:2.3.eng: Dullness, drowsiness, restlessness, remorse, lack of faith, and negligence.

an6.66:2.4.pli: ime kho, bhikkhave, cha dhamme pahāya bhabbo arahattaṃ sacchikātun”ti.
an6.66:2.4.eng: After giving up these six things you can realize perfection.”
